author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Iga Swiatek Dominates in French Open Final for Championship
description: Swiatek, 21, beat Coco Gauff, the 18-year-old American prodigy, 6-1, 6-3, in just over an hour.
content: PARIS — After winning her first French Open out of season in October as an unseeded teenager, Iga Swiatek proved that was anything but a fluke by winning the title again in the spring as an overwhelming favorite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Dispatcher Fired Over Mishandling 911 Call During Buffalo Shooting
description: A Tops supermarket office manager said a dispatcher yelled at her for whispering, as she hid during the shooting, and hung up on her.
content: An emergency services dispatcher in Buffalo who was accused of hanging up on a 911 call from a supermarket employee during the racist shooting rampage last month was fired on Thursday, an official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘Wherever I Am Is Hong Kong’: Migrants Build a New Life in the U.K.
description: More than a year after they first began arriving in Britain under a new visa program, people from Hong Kong are settling into their new home. But they still long for the one they left behind.
content: SUTTON, England — The days were short, and so much colder than the ones they had known, when Eric Wong and his family set foot in London in the winter of 2020 to start new lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Evacuated From Beach Home After Plane Enters Restricted Airspace
description: A White House official said the incursion appeared to be an accident and that there was no threat to the president or his family.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden was briefly evacuated Saturday from his beach home in Rehoboth Beach, Del., after a small private plane accidentally flew into restricted airspace, according to White House and Secret Service officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margalit Fox
title: Ann Turner Cook Dies at 95; Her Face Sold Baby Food by the Billions
description: Her likeness as an infant has graced the labels on Gerber products for more than 90 years, though for decades her identity was not disclosed.
content: For years, the suspects were legion:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Johnny and Amber: Trouble in Paradise
description: The starry, sorry spectacle and why we watched it.
content: WASHINGTON — Over the years, when I felt twinges of envy, gazing at other people’s glamorous travelogues on Instagram or visiting friends who seemed to have the perfect lives, I summoned these comforting lines:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Mothers Step In to Donate Milk They Can Spare
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 4, 2022.
content: “I was flabbergasted because it’s not every day that someone offers breast milk, certainly not for free.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Don’t Referee Every Schoolyard Conflict. Help Kids Learn to Solve Them on Their Own.
description: When parents interfere too much, children miss out on building an essential life skill.
content: Most days when I pick my two daughters up from elementary school, they happily bound out the door — another day of high-spirited chatter about whom they played with and some facts about the Battle of Saratoga. But occasionally, there’s some kind of schoolyard spat. One of them will stomp out, furious about some perceived slight, which they reveal to me on our way home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: As Geese Leave Mementos, a California City Weighs a Cull
description: The proposal has pit animal rights activists against officials in Foster City, Calif., where Canada geese have been fouling up public spaces with their feces. “It’s everywhere,” the mayor said.
content: They poop on the lawn. They poop in the park. That poop makes its way into the waterways. Officials in one California city have decided that enough is enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Killing in Wisconsin Was Motivated by Judicial Matter, Attorney General Says
description: The attorney general said that the fatal shooting of a 68-year-old man on Friday appeared to be “based on some sort of court case or court cases,” and that others might have been targeted.
content: The attorney general of Wisconsin said that a 68-year-old man was killed in his home on Friday in a shooting that appeared to be motivated by a judicial matter, and that others might have been targeted in connection to the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Baby Formula Plant That Shut Down and Fueled Crisis Restarts Production
description: Abbott Nutrition said that its plant in Sturgis, Mich., resumed production of EleCare and other formulas on Saturday.
content: Abbott Nutrition, the company that fueled a national shortage of baby formula when it shut down a leading production plant in February because of contamination concerns, said on Saturday that the site has restarted producing EleCare and other formulas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Warship Arrives in Stockholm for Military Exercises, and as a Warning
description: For Sweden and Finland, which want to join NATO, the U.S.S. Kearsarge is a promise of the protection that membership in the alliance would bring against President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
content: ABOARD U.S.S. KEARSARGE, in the port of Stockholm — If ever there was a potent symbol of how much Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has altered Europe, the sight of this enormous warship, bristling with 26 warplanes and 2,400 Marines and sailors, moored among the pleasure craft and tour boats that ply this port, would certainly be it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle and Brian X. Chen
title: Apple Starts Connecting the Dots for Its Next Big Thing
description: The company has enlisted Hollywood directors like Jon Favreau to help its effort to create products that blend the physical and virtual worlds.
content: Nearly 15 years after the iPhone sparked the smartphone revolution, Apple is assembling the pieces for what it hopes will become its next business-altering device: a headset that blends the digital world with the real one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Giang
title: The Office Monsters Are Trying to Claw Their Way Back to 2019
description: Some corporate leaders are grasping at whatever they can to get back to the way things were. But they might find themselves fighting a culture shift beyond their control.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of May 30, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Summer Vacation Movies
description: They offer a double dose of escape.
content: June arrives freighted with possibility. It brings summer’s first act, and the trappings of the season loom in the imagination: barbecues and beach trips, some time out of town if you’re lucky. The promise of June is one of escape: from winter, from the school year, from everyday life into a more magical and sun-dappled one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: We Can’t Be Ukraine Hawks Forever
description: A hawkish policy has worked so far. A hawkish grand strategy is still unrealistic.
content: Sure, it works in practice, but does it work in theory? Over the years I’ve heard this parody of academic pomposity put in the lips of various targets, from French intellectuals to University of Chicago economists. Lately, though, I’ve begun thinking it myself — about the hawkish side in the debate over the Ukraine War, whose practical policies have so far achieved favorable results but whose deeper theories of the conflict still seem implausible, unworkable or dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: For Beto O’Rourke, Talk of Gun Control Has Become Both a Political Risk and Reward
description: Mr. O’Rourke is returning to an issue that had haunted his campaign for Texas governor for months.
content: DALLAS — When Beto O’Rourke interrupted a news conference in Uvalde to criticize Gov. Greg Abbott, Jason Smith bristled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeke Hausfather
title: Let’s Not Pretend Planting Trees Is a Permanent Climate Solution
description: Carbon emissions are forever so carbon removal should be, too.
content: Trees are our original carbon removal technology: Through photosynthesis, they pull carbon dioxide out of the air and store it. They have lately been touted as a climate savior, a way to rapidly reduce the carbon dioxide that has accumulated in the atmosphere as we cut our emissions. A “trillion trees” initiative was launched with much fanfare at the World Economic Forum in Davos back in 2020, and it was one of the few climate solutions embraced by the Trump administration. Planting trees and protecting forests are a major part of many corporate efforts to offset emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Elkins
title: The Imperial Fictions Behind the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee
description: Britain’s monarchy cannot be separated from its empire.
content: “I declare before you all that my whole life whether it be long or short shall be devoted to your service and the service of our great imperial family to which we all belong.” It is said that Princess Elizabeth wept when first reading this speech. Marking her 21st birthday, and broadcast in 1947 from a bougainvillea-studded garden in Cape Town, it heralded the young royal’s future embodiment of Britain and its empire and Commonwealth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Amid a Wave of Mass Shootings in the U.S., Canada Tightens Gun Laws
description: The handgun market in Canada has been frozen as Parliament reviews sweeping legal changes, including a mandatory buyback of some rifles.
content: It was an unusually hectic week of announcements and news from Canada: a freeze on handgun sales and transfers; the introduction of a gun reform bill that includes a buyback of “military-style assault rifles”; another damning report on sexual misconduct in the military with a road map for ending it; decriminalization of the possession of small amounts of opioids and other illegal drugs in British Columbia; and a vote in Ontario that returned its Progressive Conservative government to power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Ex-Air Force Sergeant Sentenced to 41 Years for Murder of Federal Officer
description: Steven Carrillo pleaded guilty to a premeditated attack on law enforcement officers motivated by his support for an online anti-government movement.
content: A former Air Force sergeant who participated online in an extremist anti-government movement was sentenced on Friday to 41 years in prison for murdering a federal security officer and injuring another outside a courthouse in Oakland, Calif., according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Jubilee Honors Britain’s Queen, but Also Highlights Her Increasing Absences
description: Throngs of admirers cheered Queen Elizabeth II at her Platinum Jubilee appearance on Thursday, but she was unable to attend a service on Friday. Prince Charles, in a familiar role, played the understudy.
content: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II’s Platinum Jubilee has become a party without its guest of honor. Her absence is a metaphor for the twilight of Britain’s second Elizabethan Age, an awkward limbo in which the 96-year-old queen still reigns but has, in many ways, been replaced by her eldest son and heir, Prince Charles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: If New York City Gets Las Vegas-Style Casinos, What Else Will It Get?
description: Whether casinos deliver on their long-term economic promises has long been debated. Evidence from other cities suggests they rarely do.
content: Before too long, New Yorkers and the millions of tourists who visit the city every year may have a new way to test their luck — and part with their money — amid the bright lights and skyscrapers of Midtown Manhattan: hands of blackjack or spins of the roulette wheel inside a new casino with all the trappings of Las Vegas, down to the incessant ringing and fluorescent flashing of a sea of slot machines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Neil Vigdor
title: Three G.O.P. candidates for Michigan governor will stay off the ballot, the state’s Supreme Court rules.
description: The decision leaves Republicans greatly weakened in their primary for governor in a key battleground state, and strengthens the hand of Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat.
content: The Michigan Supreme Court on Friday denied requests by three Republican candidates for governor to be restored to the August primary ballot, after state election officials found that their campaigns had submitted forged signatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Emily Rhyne and Ivan Pierre Aguirre
title: Mariachis Ride Into Uvalde With Songs of Heartache and Hope
description: With trumpets, strings and serenades, their music traces the arc of life. It often accompanies moments of jubilation, but it can also speak to a community’s profound sorrow.
content: UVALDE, Texas — A bus rolled in off the dusty highway and into the heart of a town mired in sorrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: London Police Evacuate Trafalgar Square, but Say ‘Incident Has Now Been Concluded’
description: The evacuation of the square in Central London rattled the capital on the third day of Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee. The police later said it was not related to terrorism.
content: LONDON — The police evacuated crowds and cordoned off Trafalgar Square in central London on Saturday morning after responding to a report of a suspicious vehicle, rattling the British capital on the third day of Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: When Every Conversation Becomes a Game, We All Lose
description: A disagreement is too often a wish to destroy.
content: I graduated from college in 2009. Since then, I’ve lived in two cities and had at least eight jobs, three of which I was pretty good at. And I think, or at least I hope, I’ve learned a lot. And perhaps the biggest lesson I’ve learned is about learning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scaachi Koul
title: An Engaged Woman Sees the Ghosts of Relationships Past
description: In her second novel, “Cult Classic,” Sloane Crosley brings an essayist’s eye for detail to the plight of seeking love.
content: Of the several common New York nightmares I’m afraid of — like tripping down the subway stairs, being touched on my bare skin by a rat or sweating so hard in the summer that my eyeliner ends up on my chest — running into an ex is high on my list. It is a unique kind of horror story, one that oddly promises a juicy little thrill, but a horror all the same. Just because something’s titillating and a little bit exciting and holds the promise of something illicit and fulfilling doesn’t mean it isn’t terrifying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Easy to Overlook, He’s Not Too Small for the Celtics’ Big Moments
description: The second-year Boston guard Payton Pritchard is just over six feet tall, which can be a problem on defense. But clutch shooting is his strength.
content: It was one of the more amusing moments of the N.B.A. playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can My Co-op Charge Me to Get Rid of the Bedbugs in My Apartment?
description: Landlords and co-op boards are legally obligated to exterminate bedbug infestations. But there are other costs involved that can fall on residents.
content: Q: I live in a small Manhattan co-op. Last summer, my apartment had a bedbug infestation, which I treated by calling an exterminator. The process entailed multiple visits and cost several thousand dollars. I never billed the co-op, partly out of embarrassment, even though I might have been able to. I later learned that my upstairs neighbor also had bedbugs and treated them on her own. Now a year later, the board is updating its proprietary lease so that the treatment of bedbugs is entirely the responsibility of tenants. Can it do that? Do any state laws govern a co-op’s response to bug infestations?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Republicans Elevate Diverse Recruits in Bid to Win House Majority
description: The G.O.P.’s plan to win back the House rests on candidates of color who leaders hope can help broaden the party’s appeal.
content: TUCSON, Ariz. — When Juan Ciscomani first brought his family to his new congressional campaign office in the Catalina foothills, his father asked him: “Do you know where we are?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Adelson, Amanda Holpuch and Nick Madigan
title: Tropical Weather Floods Miami Streets, Stranding Some Motorists
description: The storm system in South Florida also caused a sewage overflow in Miami-Dade County.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — The first tropical threat of the hurricane season in Florida drenched the southern part of the state, leaving behind flooded streets, motorists calling for help from stranded cars and even a sewage overflow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Mentor to a Queen
description: Scott Earl brings us a Saturday puzzle with panache.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Scott Earl’s Saturday debut (after a couple of Times Friday grids) and my first thought while scanning its clue set was, “This is one for the trivia buffs.” I stand by that, and freely admit that a lot of the factoids called for today are new to me — generous crosses saved my solve a number of times. I enjoyed all that deduction, though, and relished picking up on some twists that make this puzzle quite witty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu, Chris Buckley, Austin Ramzy and Isabella Kwai
title: Mourning Tiananmen’s Victims, and the Hong Kong That Was
description: In Taiwan and elsewhere, people met on Saturday to remember those killed in China in 1989 — and the freedoms lost in Hong Kong, where such vigils are now unthinkable.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — For decades, a large candlelight vigil was held in Hong Kong each June 4, to commemorate those killed when Chinese soldiers crushed the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: DeLillo, Psychiatry and a Novella
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Dear Readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allie Jones and Cassidy Araiza
title: The Bachelorette Party Comes for Scottsdale
description: Local hot-air balloon and desert Jeep tour outfitters are crawling with groups of women belting out Katy Perry songs and only occasionally throwing up.
content: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — On a recent Friday afternoon, at a $5 million mansion turned short-term rental property just outside Scottsdale city limits, God’s perfection revealed itself as elements of the natural and synthetic world collided at Marissa Sklar’s bachelorette party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: A Farmer Holds On, a Fraying Lifeline for a Besieged Corner of Ukraine
description: Most farmers have fled the Russian advance, but Oleksandr Chaplik has stayed, despite the lethal risks and a lack of workers, water and power.
content: SIVERSK DISTRICT, Ukraine — One of the few civilians still driving on a road leading toward the battle front, Oleksandr Chaplik skidded to a stop and leaned out the car window to swap information with a villager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Barry Sussman, Washington Post Watergate Editor, Dies at 87
description: He worked closely with the reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein in covering the break-in and the subsequent scandal that doomed Richard Nixon.
content: Barry Sussman, the editor closest to The Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein as they covered the Watergate break-in and pursued the subsequent scandal that led to President Richard M. Nixon’s resignation, died on Wednesday at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Fetterman’s Heart Issues Add Wild Card to Key Pennsylvania Senate Race
description: Part of John Fetterman’s appeal as the Democratic Senate nominee has stemmed from his brash sense of vitality. It’s not clear if his recent stroke and absence from the trail will affect that.
content: Just three weeks ago, a varied cross-section of Pennsylvania Democrats put its hopes on the broad shoulders of John Fetterman, confident that the commonwealth’s burly lieutenant governor could vanquish anything or anyone that a fractured Republican Party could throw at him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Mike Baker
title: For Families in Uvalde, Laws Limit Paths to Accountability
description: Police officers rarely face criminal charges for inaction, and limits on civil lawsuits shield school districts and the police.
content: In the aftermath of the mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, parents and community members have clamored for accountability, asking how officers allowed a gunman to remain inside a locked classroom with injured students for more than an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Jason Horowitz
title: As Battles Rage, Ukraine Rejects Macron Plea Not to ‘Humiliate’ Russia
description: Amid reports of battlefield gains by Ukraine, an official angrily rejected Mr. Macron’s advice, saying it “can only humiliate France.”
content: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — As Ukrainian troops tried to claw back territory and stave off a blistering Russian assault along the country’s embattled eastern front, the government on Saturday sought also to repel a demand earlier in the day by President Emmanuel Macron of France that Moscow not be humiliated to improve chances of reaching a diplomatic solution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: Fandom Is Out of Control
description: What drives a grown person to travel to a courthouse in Virginia to hurl insults at someone she has never met, about behavior she didn’t witness and money she is not owed?
content: “Boo! Where’s the money?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Reporting Home Covid Test Results Can Be Confusing. Here’s How to Do It.
description: In many places, there is no system for sharing home test results with health officials, but the information may still be beneficial for public health.
content: So, you got a positive result on your home test for Covid-19. What do you do next? In addition to everything else on your plate — isolating and notifying close contacts, taking time off work and rescheduling appointments — it’s good practice to report your test results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Tanned, Buff and Ready to Pose, Gaza Bodybuilders Feel Weight of Blockade
description: Bodybuilding is popular among Palestinians living in Gaza, but travel restrictions and other obstacles as a result of the Israeli blockade make competing abroad a struggle.
content: GAZA CITY — Rain, shine or war, one bodybuilder’s day begins with a cup of instant espresso coffee — no sugar or milk — and a power walk, usually along the beachfront boardwalk of Gaza City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oskar Garcia
title: Here’s how to watch or stream the final.
description: In the United States, the final will air on NBC and the NBC Sports website and app.
content: For fans waking up early to watch the French Open in the United States, matches throughout the tournament have been spread across a few television channels and streaming outlets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Let’s Get Literature
description: Christina Iverson and Katie Hale shoot a puzzle through a canon.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Christina Iverson lives in Ames, Iowa, and is the assistant crossword editor for The Los Angeles Times; Katie Hale is a full-time parent in London. The idea for this grid started with Katie; she laid eyes on a copy of “The Great Gatsby,” and the phrase THROW A FITZGERALD popped into her head. Inspiration!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: A ‘Steel Cable’ That Connects the Mets to the Dodgers
description: A tense series between the N.L.’s best teams paused to honor Gil Hodges, an icon for both franchises who had his No. 14 jersey retired by Los Angeles.
content: LOS ANGELES — The connective tissues stretch all the way across the country and back again, binding Brooklyn, Los Angeles and Queens. Through the years, through all the true bounces and bad hops and yellowed pages, the contents of this baseball triangle remain snugly bound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lee Cole
title: In Small-Town Maine, Things Are More Sinister Than They Seem
description: Adam White’s debut novel, “The Midcoast,” takes readers to Damariscotta, where a native son becomes obsessed with a lobsterman’s fortune.
content: Place, like class, is often understood by Americans to be a temporary state of affairs on the way to something — or somewhere — better. This rootlessness, this faith in mobility, has found its way into many contemporary books, wherein the settings are more like painted backdrops, inert and somewhat arbitrary. But there’s an older, perennial instinct in American literature to claim a place as one’s own, to study it minutely and evoke its ultimate mystery. It’s this instinct that’s on full display in Adam White’s vividly rendered debut novel, “The Midcoast.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russia increases its use of air power to support its fight in the Donbas region, an intelligence report says.
description: Ukrainian forces poured men and armor toward the front line in Sievierodonetsk on Friday, and a military official said Ukrainian troops had managed to push Russian forces back by 20 percent.
content: Russia has increased its use of air power in support of artillery and ground troops who are fighting to expand their territory in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, including in the city of Sievierodonetsk, a British intelligence report said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Perrotta
title: A Memoir of Friendship and Death in a Vacation Idyll
description: Charles McGrath’s “The Summer Friend” recounts happy days and the gut punch of an untimely death.
content: THE SUMMER FRIENDA MemoirBy Charles McGrath
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
title: Senior Iranian Officer Dies, Leaving Questions About His Death
description: Col. Ali Esmaelzadeh was the second high-ranking officer of the same unit to die in a week. The circumstances were unclear, and Iranian news media provided conflicting reports.
content: The death of a senior Iranian military officer at his home in a Tehran suburb a week ago has fueled conflicting reports that he fell from a balcony, committed suicide or was killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Lee Taete
title: Arcades, Churches and Laundromats: A Trucker’s Haven on the Precipice of Change
description: As truck drivers are forced to adapt to increasing difficulties on the road, the support system that serves them is at risk of disappearing.
content: The Petro Travel Center on Interstate 10 in Ontario, Calif., is one of scores across the country. At the front of the building are the things road trippers see when they stop for gas or snacks: a convenience store, restrooms and some dining options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sally L. Satel
title: The ‘Open Secret’ on Getting a Safe Abortion Before Roe v. Wade
description: Psychiatrists were once arbiters of abortion access. Will they resume that role post-Roe?
content: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, will psychiatrists resume their pre-Roe role as arbiters of abortion access? The law once compelled psychiatrists and pregnant women to perform dishonest rituals to get abortions. Will psychiatrists once again need to be complicit post-Roe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Quoctrung Bui, Alicia Parlapiano and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: The Mass Shootings Where Stricter Gun Laws Might Have Made a Difference
description: Four measures could have affected shootings that killed 446 people since the Columbine massacre in 1999.
content: Four measures could have affected shootings that killed 446 people since the Columbine massacre in 1999.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: A Little Hong Kong in London
description: More than a year after they first began arriving in Britain under a new visa program, migrants from Hong Kong are settling into their new home. Here's what some of them told me about their experience so far.
content: More than a year after they first began arriving in Britain under a new visa program, migrants from Hong Kong are settling into their new home. Here's what some of them told me about their experience so far.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Asylum Seekers Cross The Border
description: How Asylum Seekers Cross The Border
content: How Asylum Seekers Cross The Border
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Tropical Weather System Floods the Streets of Miami
description: Drivers in Miami faced slashing rains and flooded streets as a rapidly growing weather system moved into the South Florida region.
content: Drivers in Miami faced slashing rains and flooded streets as a rapidly growing weather system moved into the South Florida region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Debate Over the Best Way to Teach Reading
description: Readers discuss an article about a trend back to emphasizing phonics.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 4, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 4, 2022.
content: An article on March 23 about a potential deal among six groups of victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks to divide Afghan central bank assets misstated the first name of a member of a group of Sept. 11 plaintiffs, known as the Ashton case. He is Brett Eagleson, not Brian. This correction was delayed because editors were only recently made aware of the error.
source.name: The New York Times
